title: Linux ranlib Command with Practical Examples
description: Explore the Linux ranlib command, learn how to create and manage static libraries, and discover practical examples to enhance your system administration skills.

meta.title: Linux ranlib Command with Practical Examples
meta.description: Explore the Linux ranlib command, learn how to create and manage static libraries, and discover practical examples to enhance your system administration skills.
meta.keywords: Linux, ranlib, static library, object files, command-line, system administration

steps.title: Understand the Purpose of ranlib Command

verify.name: Verify the static library is created
verify.hint: Make sure you have created the static library file `libmylib.a` using the `ar` command.

verify.name: Verify the `ranlib` command is used
verify.hint: Make sure you have used the `ranlib` command to update the symbol table in the static library `libmylib.a`.

steps.title: Create a Static Library and Use ranlib

verify.name: Verify the static library is created
verify.hint: Make sure you have created the static library file `libmylib.a` using the `ar` command.

verify.name: Verify the `ranlib` command is used
verify.hint: Make sure you have used the `ranlib` command to update the symbol table in the static library `libmylib.a`.

verify.name: Verify the program links against the static library
verify.hint: Make sure you have used the `-L.` and `-lmylib` options to link the program against the static library `libmylib.a`.

verify.name: Verify the symbols in the static library
verify.hint: Make sure the `nm` command shows the `myfunction` symbol defined in the static library `libmylib.a`.

verify.name: Verify the object file in the static library
verify.hint: Make sure the `ar -t` command shows the `mylib.o` object file in the static library `libmylib.a`.

verify.name: Verify the program links against the static library
verify.hint: Make sure you have used the `-L.` and `-lmylib` options to link the program against the static library `libmylib.a`, and that the program runs correctly.
